* sigh *
Where to begin... Ok, so I've watched this anime about a week ago and I had to let it sink it for a few days, because I honestly didn't know how I felt about it. Still don't by the way.
I came across it on CR and after reading all of the reviews, I was really quited intrueged. It couldn't be THAT bad, could it?
Well, it was... and it wasn't. I get why this anime got so many bad reviews and I don't disagree with the reasoning behind it. However, despite it's many many many many many many flaws, I didn't find it thathorrible, but that has actually very little to do with the anime itself and I'll get to why that is in a minute. Let me break down this review in 7 parts because there's a lot to talk about. 

(Please forgive any mistakes, grammar or other, english is not my mothertongue.)


WARNING: there will be some spoilers.


1 - Story


Ok, there is no story. Well, not really anyway. As with most of the reverse-harem shows I've watched thus far, I felt like this anime could've been great, outstanding even, if they stayed closer to the source material. And with closer I mean that they could've given us more, much more, but they chose not to for whatever reason. Granted, the source material is, to say the least, very disturbing, but that's what makes it so interesting. Like what Black Butler - Book of Circus did (gosh, it took me a solid few days to get over that one). Instead they give us 11 episodes filled with the brothers sucking her blood over and over again - which gets old real fast - and one actually rather interesting episode. I get it, it's very sexualized like ooh-aah-look-at-what-they're-doing-gasp-blush-yadayada. I think that's what we're supposed to love, but it was way too much and way too frequent. I was quickly bored out of my mind. I rolled my eyes everytime it happened.

But what really boggled my mind were the last 2 episodes, especially the last one. There is where the story actually pickes up (only to end in that same episode); Things were finally happening and I felt that they could've built around this episode and stretched it out throughout the show. But they didn't. Why? Because reasons.

(NOTE: I've also watched season 2 and it's the same thing)


2 - Art


The art is simply stunning and I have actually no negative things to say about it, what makes it even worse. It's like getting a beautifully wrapped present with nothing in it. 


4 - Sound


The music is rather good, I even have one song added to my anime playlist which I only do when I really enjoy it, but there's only one so I wouldn't say it was really outstanding. It did fit the anime rather well tho.


5 - Character


And here is where the real issue lies. Let's start with our "heroine"... Yui. 


After watching the first episode, my first impression of her was: "Well, she's not too bad, I don't know what other people are complaining about." After episode 2 and 3, I was like: "Ok, I'm starting to get it" and after watching half of this anime, I was completely over it. Like done. Finito.

My God in the Heavens Above, she is so unbelievably dull and annoyingly stupid, I actually found myself agreeing with most of the brothers.

There is one scene where one of them says to her: "You are really stupid, you know" or something along those lines and I yelled at my TV: "YES, SHE IS! SHE REALLY REALLY IS!" All these brothers force themselves onto her and all she can say is: "Please, let go!" Sis, after they sucked your blood for the umpteenth time, you should know by now that THEY WILL NOT LET YOU GO! Kick! Scream! Punch! Do something! She even has a knife that could kill or at the very least hurt them, but does she use it? No, because why would she(!) You could actually make a drinking game out of this (spoiler-alert: you will get hammered). At this point, I couldn't even blame them anymore and that's not something I like to do, especially when it's borderline-rapey, but girl...

But then again she really is stupid. Second example: one of the brothers - one of the nicer ones - gives her a chance to leave, which she initially intends to do. She's in her room packing her bags and suddenly she stops, saying to herself: "No, I have to find out more why this or that happened." and I was like: "BITCH, can't you do that from afar?!?" Go to the church where they left you, go to where your father lives, go to the police, hell, go anywhere for that matter." UGH!


Now for the brothers, this is where things (could) get interesting, but here is where it all went wrong. The brothers are by far the best part of this anime and there were plenty of chances to delve deeper into their backstory which they kinda did... Or didn't they? Now here is where my Wiki-searching-ability comes in. After the first few episodes, I really wanted to know more about what the story actually was or rather could be since I had the feeling they weren't going to give me much. And after reading the Wiki, I really understood why the brothers were the way they were and even felt for them. Their past and upbringing was so gruesome, so abusive that they were denied any kind of real love (which actually has a reasoning behind it, but I think you can already guess that it's not in the anime - *major sigh*). Add in the fact that they are bloodthirsty vampires, you could really understand and kinda forgive their rudeness and rapey actions. Problem is that you wouldn't know that by watching the anime by itself and that's the biggest miss on the creators' part. It's like those people who're always yelling when a movie based on a book gets negative reviews: "But you guys, the book is soooo much better." Sure, Elizabeth, but a film and anime should be able to stand on it's own. And to be quite honest, I got more out of reading the Wiki-page than from the anime itself. There was so much to work with, there was so much room for character development or at least something were we as the viewers could relate to the characters, feel for them, care for them, especially since their target audience are women. But instead, what they showed us was so little and extremely confusing that I honestly don't know if I could've followed it without the extra information I've gotten from the net. Missed chances, as with so many reverse-harem shows. It actually angers me if I'm really honest.


6 -Enjoyment 


Eh. Did I enjoy it? I honestly don't know. The only thing I enjoyed were the brothers, but again, that's mostly because of what I knew from reading the Wiki. If I didn't do that, well... There is not much to enjoy. Yes, I had my favorite (Ayato) and yes, the last episode was kinda good, but yeah... I stopped watching 3 times because I was so bored and annoyed only to start watching it again. It's like this weird mysogynistic train crash which would've fueled the fire of Lucifer in my heart if this would've happened in real life or even in a live-action show, yet oddly enough that doesn't happen while watching this anime. Instead I was in a state of disbelief and I was constantly asking myself how in the hell did this even got made the way it is. This anime is a weird one, it truly is.


7 - Overall


I wouldn't recommend this anime, because there's nothing to recommend, especially if you are sensitive to rape-like scenes or if you really enjoy character development or just a good story. I wouldn't even recommend it to reverse-harem or otome-game-based-anime-fans. Chances are you'll really be disappointed. Instead I'll say: read the Wiki-page or play the games (I haven't played them myself, but I will in the near future). 

There could be a possibility that they will delve deeper into the actual story, which is rather interesting, especially the father (who's not even in the anime, not really anyway) and he could've really made the story better: the elusive and mysterious Vampire King, a man with an actual plan. Add in his younger brother who's aiming for his throne through manipulations and extreme deviousness, his wives and the interaction between them, his true motivation and why the brothers are the way they are. Like come on, the story practically writes itself. But after watching 2 seasons (and season 2 isn't actually a continuation of the anime but rather a spin-off with a whole new bunch of brothers (why I ask you??)) I don't hold my breath.


SIDE NOTE: reverse-harem shows and even otome games (I'm very ashamed to admit it) became one of my guilty pleasures, but I'm still waiting on one where the heroine actually is a heroine and not a dull, stuttering, stupid and clueless girl. As a woman, I actually find this quite offensive. UtaPri, Brother's Conflict, Some-Show-About-A-Girl-Who-Has-To-Live-With-Gods-But-I-Cant-Remember-The-Name-Exactly, they all have the same in common. A very dull and empty shell of a main character.


Let's be honest: how badass would this show be if the heroine actually had a set of balls and would stand up for herself which could in turn help the other characters in their development? You know, like actual relationships or friendships? 


*deep sigh*

Diabolik Lovers gets a bad rep because it lacks plot, character dynamics and overall realism.  But that's the thing about Diabolik Lovers, it wasn't trying to romance you in those elements.
You have to see the show for what it is.  See, the first thing you should know about Diabolik Lovers (DL) is that this whole series is based on a fantasy choose-your-ending love game featuring dark vampires.  That alone should tell you that the only side of you Diabolik Lovers wants to appeal to is your lustful side.  From that perspective, DL does it's job perfectly.
In fact, for an anime madesolely for servicing it's audience in a very specific way, the plot is fair.  It's interesting enough.  Was it moving, emotional or even believable?  No.  But was it supposed to be?  Nope! The plot is only needed to give the lusty moments within the anime context.


Asking for a real plot from a show like Diabolik Lovers is both pointless and counter-productive. Silly gooses.


Like the plot, the main character Yui gets a lot of criticism as well, for not being smart, strong or even interesting.  But much like how comic book artists purposely make heroes like Superman's features vague and inexact, Yui was carefully constructed to be personality-less and direction-less.  This clean-slate of a protagonist allows members of the audience more agency, providing them an easy pair of shoes to stick their feet in for better experience, and better fantasy.  This anime is all about the you, the audience, after all.


Yui's weak inability to fight and submission also matches with a vampire's inhumane strength.  It also allows her male counterparts the freedom they need to provide proper fan service to us.  It's all on purpose, people.


Now, the art, the sound, the enjoyment... This is where DL was trying.  For an anime that had one specific, unconventional goal of simply catering to the lustful side of their audience, I think DL nailed it.  The art is beautiful, the music, silences, and voice acting are convincing, and it was certainly enjoyable to watch.  It 


This show is one of the most controversial that I've come across, and I think it's because most people who are used to classic shoujo harem just don't know what to do with a show like Diabolik Lovers.  But if you see it for what it is, a lust-filled dating game turned into a TV show, you must admit the creators did very well.  A+ and I'm hoping for season 3!

All right, what the hell. I just finished this anime recently, so I might as well write it up while it's fresh in my mind. Maybe this will be my new hobby. Well, if you decide to watch Diabolik Lovers, then brace yourself for the ultimate cringe.
Story: 2/10 Ugh, the story (or lack of it) is abominable. All it consists is the protagonist getting drained by each of the brothers. What else is there to say?
Art: 7/10 Admittedly, the art is one of the more positive aspects of the show. It was the main reason why I decided to watch this show. The characters eachhave their own unique color scheme that I really adore. And who can go wrong with pastel gradient hair? But even so, that doesn't save this monstrosity.


Sound: 6/10 I have mixed feelings about the sound. On one hand, the OP and ending songs are quite catchy. Both really fit the sadism and carnality Diabolik Lovers ramps up. The dubbed voices were overall tolerable. (Although I can't look at Asura from Soul Eater the same way again, knowing that the VA for him also voices one of the douchebag vampires.) But on the other end of the spectrum, the vampire suckling noises are downright catatonic. I'd almost rather hear nails dragged across a chalkboard. 


Characters: 3/10 Let me tell you, there is absolutely no character development whatsoever. Nearly all the characters were extremely appalling. The protagonist has no personality or backbone. She's pretty much a walking bloodbank. She lets herself get sucked by each of the brothers without trying to fight back. It's pathetic. Also, nearly all the vampires have varying levels of psychopathy and sadism. (Well, there was one vampire I kind of liked, although his debut involved him punching a freaking wall.) Finally, the villains were complete bores and were absolutely unnecessary. They had barely any charisma that would've painted them as memorable.  


Enjoyment: 3/10 My instincts want me to give this a 2, but I'll bump it up a point just for the one character I like, the art, and how "decent" the sound is. I guess it was a good test of my strength enduring these episodes. (On a final note, I would add that the ending was completely predictable. Typical for masochistic vampire "romances.")


Overall: 3/10 OK, I confess. Even though I read the reviews on how horrible it was on here, I had to see how terrible it was myself. And I wasn't disappointed! It's a wonder I made it through the dozen, especially since I was wincing the entirety of the premiere. Perhaps I am a masochist.


Well, I see there are some sequels to this abomination. To watch or not to watch? That is the question at hand.
